Lignin valorization has attracted significant attention in recent years due to its abundance and potential as a renewable organic carbon resource to produce a variety of value-added chemicals and fuel additives. Catalytic upgrading of lignin faces challenges due to its complex structure and an active catalyst with selective surface properties is needed to break the stable C–O and C–C interunit linkages. In the present work, we developed a series of multifunctional Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts with varying surface acidic properties and explored their potential upon hydrogenolysis of lignin model compound eugenol. Textural and surface acidic properties of the prepared materials were studied by means of different techniques such as N2-physisorption, NH3-TPD, XRD, SEM-EDS, Raman spectra, FT-IR, and TEM. Our catalytic results revealed synergistic role of acid and metal sites upon catalyst performance, whereupon high yields of hydrocarbons (86.9–100 wt.%) were obtained with selective cleavage of the methoxy and hydroxy groups under milder conditions. A kinetic study further identified the reaction mechanism and determined a rate law and partial reaction orders. This research advances the understanding of catalyst design for upgrading of the lignin or lignin monomers into value added chemicals. and on the other hand, contributes to sustainable development by maximizing biomass usage and providing environmentally friendly alternatives in renewable energy. Graphical abstract Multifunctional Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts are developed with varying surface acidity for hydrodeoxygenation of eugenol, a lignin model compound. The catalysts show superior activity and reusability for hydrocarbon production, selectively cleaving methoxy and hydroxy groups, and outperforming other catalysts such as Ru/TiO2 and commercial Ru/C. The research enhances catalyst design for lignin upgrading, supporting sustainable biomass utilization and renewable energy solutions. Nomenclature c concentration D distance from values EUG eugenol HDO hydrodeoxygenation k kinetic constant m mass MW molecular weight R rate of reaction r rate of production R2 coefficient of determination T temperature t time ν reaction mechanism 1 Introduction Lignin, a highly abundant natural polymer present in lignocellulosic biomass, constitutes approximately 20-35% of such materials. It is mainly composed of phenolic compounds interconnected through a complex network of covalent bonds, including ether (C-O) and carbon-carbon linkages, giving lignin its three-dimensional, irregular structure [1,2] (Fig. 1 ). The primary monomers in lignin, coniferyl, sinapyl, and p-coumaryl alcohol, are joined by a combination of C-O and C-C bonds, with C-O bonds (e.g., β-O-4, α-O-4, 4-O-5) constituting the majority, which account for more than 70% of the total linkages [3–5]. Although lignin is produced in vast amounts (around 50 to 70 million tons each year) as a byproduct, particularly from the paper and pulp industry, it remains underutilized, with most of it being burned for energy recovery. However, lignin holds great potential for conversion into high-value chemicals and biofuels. This can be achieved through catalytic conversion processes, specifically targeting the cleavage of its challenging C-O bonds and transforming it into useful hydrocarbon fuels or aromatic chemicals [6]. Various catalysts have been developed for lignin depolymerization in biofuel applications, with a focus on cleaving C-O bonds and facilitating hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [7–9]. HDO is a chemical process for removing oxygen from oxygen-containing organic compounds, typically using hydrogen gas (H₂) in conjunction with solid acid catalysts [10,11]. Among these, niobium phosphate (NbOPO4) has shown great promise due to its stability, tunable acidity, providing both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, which are crucial for breaking down lignin's complex structure [12–14]. Despite its potential, research on NbOPO4 as a solid acid catalyst is still in its early stages in lignin conversion and other applications, such as hydroxyalkylation-alkylation of furanics for jet fuel production [15], and hydrocyclization of levulinic acid for γ-valerolactone synthesis [16]. Besides, it has been proposed that NbOPO4 can be further enhanced by incorporating metallic components such as ruthenium [17], palladium [18], platinum [19], gold [20], rhodium [21] and nickel [22]. These metals are crucial for hydrogen activation and separation, which are essential for HDO reactions. Among them, ruthenium (Ru) stands out for its good but not overly aggressive activity in hydrogen separation, as well as possessing a water-tolerant property, making it particularly suitable for the HDO process [23,24]. Although the unique properties of NbOPO4 find potential applications in heterogeneous catalytic conversion processes, Nb is less abundant on earth, and it is an expensive metal to use as a bulk catalyst for catalytic applications. In this context, supporting a minimal amount of NbOPO4 on inexpensive support materials such as silica, alumina, titania and zirconia etc. are both catalytically (effective in terms of turnover frequency) and economically (less expensive) beneficial for upscaling and possible commercialization of the process [15,16]. Additionally, supporting the catalyst on a stable oxide has proven beneficial in catalytic applications [25]. Titanium dioxide (TiO2), a thermally and chemically stable reducible oxide, which is widely used both as a catalyst and a support. It enhances catalyst durability through strong metal-support interactions, preventing leaching of the catalyst components and maintaining structural integrity under harsh reaction conditions. TiO2 also provides a medium surface area with tunable pore sizes, primarily in the mesoporous range, which is ideal for HDO reactions [26,27]. Interestingly, the combination of Ru, NbOPO4, and TiO2, although promising, has not yet been explored for lignin conversion, especially considering the tunable acidity of the catalyst, which could play a key role in improving lignin breakdown efficiency. In this study, we aim to employ the physicochemical properties of Ru, NbOPO4, and TiO2 for designing a tri-component catalyst (Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2) and investigate its performance in the HDO of lignin-model compounds, specifically eugenol. Eugenol, which contains an aromatic ring and functional groups such as methoxy and hydroxy, is structurally similar to lignin monomers, a suitable representative compound for studying the catalytic activity, selectivity, stability and reusability of the catalyst. The catalysts are characterized using N2-physisorption, NH₃-TPD, XRD, SEM-EDX, FT-IR, Raman spectra and TEM techniques to understand the structure-activity correlations. Through detailed kinetic studies, we aim to gain insights into the reaction mechanism and assess the catalyst's efficiency, not only in converting eugenol but also in maintaining its activity and reusability across multiple reaction cycles. The synergistic interaction between Ru, NbOPO4, and TiO2 will be studied to optimize C-O bond cleavage, potentially paving the way for more effective lignin valorization strategies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and chemicals Chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. LLC (Sweden), including ammonium phosphate monobasic (99%), niobium(V) chloride (99%), ruthenium (III) chloride hydrate (99%), titanium (IV) isopropoxide (97%), and Pluronic® P123 (Mn∼5,800). Acetone (99.9%), hydrochloric acid (37%), methanol (100%), ethanol (96%), and absolute ethanol (99.95%) were obtained from VWR Co. LLC (Sweden). All chemicals above were used as received without further purification. Milli-Q water was deionized and filtered before use. Instrument-grade gases including helium (99.99%), air, hydrogen (99.99%), argon (99.99%), and 5% ammonia in helium were employed for instrumentation. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of NbOPO4 NbOPO4 was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by varying concentrations of HCl (1M, 3M, 6M, 9M, 12M). Typically, 3.976 g of NbCl5 was dissolved in a 500 mL high-density polyethylene (HDPE) bottle containing 100 mL of an HCl-Milli-Q water solution, then stirred for 2 h at room temperature. Separately, 3.3852 g of ammonium phosphate monobasic (NH4H2PO4) was dissolved in 100 mL of the same HCl-Milli-Q water solution. After 2 h, the NH4H2PO4 solution was gradually added to the NbCl5 solution, and the mixture was stirred overnight at 80°C. Stirring was then stopped, and the solution was maintained at 80°C for 3 h to facilitate crystallization. The resulting material was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 95°C overnight, and finally calcined at 450°C for 5 h under a 100 L/h flow of air [15]. Product appearance: white powder. NbCl5 + 4H2O ⇋ NbO(OH)3 + 5HCl N b O ( O H ) 3 + N H 4 H 2 P O 4 + H C l → Δ N b O P O 4 + N H 4 C l + 3 H 2 O 2.2.2 Synthesis of TiO2 Mesoporous TiO2 was synthesized as a catalyst support following the procedure below. In a 1 L HDPE bottle, 24.5 mL of 37 wt.% HCl was added to 380 mL of absolute ethanol. To this, 10 g of P123 was added, and the solution was stirred vigorously at 40°C for 3 h. Subsequently, titanium (IV) isopropoxide (TIPO) was introduced into the mixture, which was then stirred for an additional 20 h at 40°C. The solution was dried at 35°C at a relative humidity of 30-50% for 7 days. To ensure complete drying, the material was further dried at 95°C for 24 h. Finally, calcination was conducted at 500°C for 5 h under a continuous 100 L/h flow of air to remove the organic template [26–28]. Product appearance: white powder. 2.2.3 Synthesis of catalyst Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 To prepare a supported material composed of 20 wt.% NbOPO4 and 80 wt.% TiO2, mesoporous TiO2 was doped with NbOPO4 using HCl solutions of varying concentrations (1M, 3M, 6M, 9M, 12M). For this, 2 g of TiO2 was added to 50 mL of HCl solution, followed by 0.663 g of NbCl5, and the mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. Separately, 0.5645 g of NH4H2PO4 was dissolved in 50 mL of HCl solution at room temperature, then added to the TiO2-NbCl5 mixture and stirred overnight at 80°C. After stirring, the solution was allowed to crystallize at 80°C for 3 h, then cooled for 2 h. The material was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried overnight at 95°C, and calcined at 450°C for 5 h under a 100 L/h flow of air. To decorate the NbOPO4/TiO2 with ruthenium (2.5 wt.% Ru), 0.0513 g of RuCl3 was dissolved in 20 mL of water, and 0.975 g of NbOPO4/TiO2 was added. The mixture was stirred vigorously overnight, dried in an oil bath for 1.5 h, then placed in an oven at 110°C overnight. Reduction was carried out under a hydrogen flow (50 mL/min) at 400°C for 4 h, followed by a nitrogen flow (50 mL/min) at room temperature for 1 h to ensure complete removal of residual hydrogen. Based on the HCl concentrations employed in the preparation step, catalysts were named 1M, 3M, 6M, 9M, and 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 accordingly. Product appearance: grey powder. 2.3 Catalyst characterization All the as-prepared Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts were extensively characterized by means of different physico-chemical techniques. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). To acquire structural insights of the catalysts, FT-IR was used with transmittance mode from 4000 cm−1 to 400 cm−1 [29]. The samples were measured with a Bruker Vertex 80 FT-IR spectrometer at a resolution of 2 cm-1 in ATR (attenuated total reflection) mode using OPUS program. Identification of the Brønsted (B) and Lewis (L) acid sites of the materials were achieved using pyridine as the probe molecule. Pyridine was adsorbed onto the samples at 80 °C for 30 min and desorbed later at 150 °C for 1 h. The samples were diluted with KBr and measured in absorbance mode using a Bruker IFS 66 v/S FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector, vacuum bench, and diffuse reflectance (DR) carousel. Raman. To implement the structural information of catalyst materials, a portable Raman BRAVO analyzer was employed with dual lasers of wavelengths 785 nm and 852 nm. Analysis was carried out in a spectral range from 3200 to 300 cm-1 at room temperature using a CCD detector and the Raman spectra were processed in program OPUS 7.8. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD). To study crystallinity of the solid catalysts, XRD measurements were carried out with 2θ angle from 10° to 70° (step size 0.00656°) using a PANalytical X’Pert3 Powder Diffractometer (Malvern Panalytical, Malvern, Worcs, UK) equipped with a Cu-Kα (λ = 1.54 Å) source and a split of 1/16 [30]. The spectra were analyzed using HighScore and Origin software programs. Scanning electron microscope (SEM). To observe surface morphologies of the catalysts, a Carl Zeiss Merlin field-emission SEM (FE-SEM, Carl Zeiss Merlin GmbH, Oberkochen, Germany) was employed, operating at 40 kV, with an in-lens secondary electron detector. Elemental compositions of the catalytic materials were obtained with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, Oxford Instruments X-MAX 80 mm2) at 5 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The structural arrangement and Ru distribution of the catalytic materials were further analyzed using TEM (JEOL 1230) operating at 80 kV. N2 physisorption. To acquire the surface properties of the catalysts, N2 adsorption−desorption analysis was performed using Tristar 3000 apparatus (Micromeritics Instrument Corp., Norcross, GA, USA). The samples were initially outgassed at 473 K for 3 h under N2 flow and then measured at liquid N2 temperature (−196°C). Specific surface area of the samples was determined by multipoint N2 sorptiometry using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (B.E.T.) principle. Pore volume, average pore size, and pore size distribution were collected using desorption isotherms of the Barrett−Joyner−Halenda (BJH) algorithm. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). Total surface acidity of the catalysts was obtained using TPD on a BELCAT II instrument (MicrotracBEL Corp.). For acidity measurements, 5 % NH3 in He was used as a probe molecule. Typically, about 60 mg of the sample was put in an adsorption vessel and the sample was evacuated at 450°C for 2 h under He flow. Then the sample was cooled down to 100 °C, saturated with 5% NH3 in He for 0.5 h, and subsequently flushed with He at 100 °C for 0.5 h to remove traces of physisorbed NH3. Later TPD was performed from 100 to 500 °C, at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under He flow. After each measurement, the amount of chemisorbed/desorbed NH3 was calculated from the calibration curves obtained from varying volumes of NH3 in He. Deconvolution of the TPD profiles was achieved with ChemMaster software (version 1.4.19, MicrotracBEL), using multiple-Gaussian distribution. 2.4 Reaction setup and catalytic experiments 2.4.1 Hydrodeoxygenation reaction of eugenol The reaction objective was to convert eugenol (a lignin-model compound) into non-oxygenated hydrocarbons. The reaction setup was followed: a batch reaction was conducted using a 15 mL autoclave equipped with a pressure gauge, an emergency relief valve, and a digital temperature controller (assembled from high-pressure 316 stainless steel Swagelok parts) (SI 1). During the reaction setup, 50 mg catalyst, 1.2 mmol eugenol, and 5 mL cyclohexane, used as solvent, were loaded into the autoclave. The reactor was then loaded and purged several times with pure H2 (99.99%) to remove all the air inside and afterwards pressurized to reach the desired H2 pressure of 50 bars. Later, the reaction mixture was heated to the required temperature (175 - 225°C) for a reaction period of 2−12 h under vigorous stirring. After the reaction time expired, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature, the H2 pressure was released, and 1000 μL of the product was collected, centrifuged, and analyzed by GC-FID and GC-MS. 2.4.2 Product analysis The products of hydrodeoxygenation reactions were determined based on GC-MS with an Agilent 6890N GC equipped with a HP-5 MS capillary column (30 m length, 0.25 mm internal diameter, 0.25 μm film thickness) and MS detector (Agilent 5579 N). The quantification of HDO products was analyzed using an Agilent 7820A GC equipped with an HP-5 MS capillary column (30 m length, 0.25 mm internal diameter, and 1 μm of film thickness) and FID detector. The GC injection port and the detector temperature were set at 250 °C while the column temperature was ramped from 50 to 250 °C, at the rate of 5 °C/min while He or N2 was used as the carrier gas. The quantification of the eugenol and deoxygenated products was based on calibration curves obtained with commercially available standard compounds (n-nonane and eugenol). The conversion is defined as follows: (1) Conversion ( % ) = ( C 0 − C t C 0 ) × 100 where C0 represents the initial concentration of eugenol, and Ct is the combined concentration of eugenol and 2-methoxy-4-propylphenol at t hours. Since eugenol is easily converted into 2-methoxy-4-propylphenol, this treatment is employed to avoid the ‘100% conversion’ effect in calculations. The selectivity is defined as below: (2) Selectivity ( % ) = C product C eugenol consumed x 100 where Cproduct and Ceugenol consumed represent the concentrations of a specific product and of eugenol consumed in the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic material characterization 3.1.1 XRD results XRD analysis provides insights into the atomic arrangement of the materials, revealing the differences between crystalline and amorphous phases. The wide-angle X-ray diffraction results for the support TiO2, NbOPO4 reference materials, and catalysts (Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2) synthesized under varying acid conditions are shown in Fig. 2 . Three distinct peaks were observed at 2θ values of 19.5°, 26.8°, and 28.6°, corresponding to the 110, 101, and 200 crystal planes of NbOPO4, respectively. Additionally, minor peaks at 40.4°, 44.9°, and 48.1° were identified, indicating the 220, 310, and 301 planes of the NbOPO4 crystalline structure [31,32]. For the Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst, the XRD patterns displayed mainly the crystalline structure of anatase TiO2, with the most prominent NbOPO4 peak observed at 2θ 28.6° (JCPDS Nr. 70–2648 and JCPDS Nr. 00–021–1272) [25], confirming the successful incorporation of NbOPO4 onto the TiO2 support. In preparation of the catalysts, the intensity of the diffraction peak 2θ 28.6° in Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts decreased as the HCl concentration used in the NbOPO4 synthesis was reduced (from 12M to 1M). Specifically, NbOPO4 in Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts synthesized at 12M and 9M HCl showed a crystalline structure, while the sample prepared at 6M, 3M, and 1M HCl was partially/entirely amorphous. This trend is expected, as crystallization is promoted in highly acidic conditions. Notably, no diffraction peaks corresponding to Ru metal were observed, suggesting the presence of finely dispersed Ru nanoparticles, which is expected, as XRD is unable to detect nanometer-level smaller particles. 3.1.2 N2 physisorption results N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were conducted for the catalysts, with the corresponding isotherms and pore size distribution curves displayed in Fig. 3 a and 3b, respectively. The surface area, pore size, and pore volume of the support and the catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . Overall, the B.E.T. surface areas of the catalysts were medium to high, reaching around 120-150 m2 g-1 with 1M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 (147.02 m2 g-1), 3M material (139.23 m2 g-1), 6M material (135.44 m2 g-1), 9M material (128.29 m2 g-1), and 12M material (152.16 m2 g-1). Besides, the mesoporous TiO2-supported catalysts exhibited a representative type IV isotherm (Fig. 3a), which remained largely unaffected by the loading of NbOPO4 and Ru, even when varying the preparation conditions. As a result, a type H1 hysteresis loop, corresponding with uniform open-ended cylindrical mesopores, was observed across all Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts, regardless of the HCl concentration, confirming the retention of original pore structure of TiO2 during catalyst and support synthesis [33,34]. The pore size distribution (Fig. 3b) consistently fell within the mesoporous range, predominantly between 5-10 nm, with 1M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 (6.88 nm), 3M material (7.22 nm), 6M material (8.20 nm), and even extended for 9M and 12M materials when their pore sizes are averaged. Notably, a substantial pore size and high surface area are important factors for catalytic performance. TiO2 as the support precursor offered several advantages for this study, as it combines a high surface area for a larger exposure of active sites, excellent chemical stability for NbOPO4 immobilization, hydrothermal stability, together with a mesoporous structure aiding in confining the Ru nanoparticles and facilitating the HDO process due to the size of the reacting molecules. 3.1.3 FT-IR and Raman The FT-IR and Raman spectra for Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 materials synthesized under varying HCl concentrations are presented in Fig. 4 a and 4b, respectively. In the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 4a), characteristic vibrations of NbOPO4 structures were observed in the regions around 540–640 cm⁻1, 920 cm⁻1, and 1000–1200 cm⁻1. The sharp band at 585 cm⁻1 is attributed to O-Nb-O(-P) stretching vibrations, while the broad, strong band centered at 1033 cm⁻1 corresponds to the stretching vibrations of phosphate species (PO4 3⁻, OPO) [35–37]. The signal intensities diminished as the HCl concentration used during the preparation of catalyst decreased, implying a higher presence of Brønsted acid sites (PO4 3⁻ species) in the 9M and 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 samples, while these sites were less prevalent in the 1M, 3M, and 6M samples, as confirmed also with pyridine-adsorbed spectra (SI 2) [25,38] where presence of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites is characterized via acid-base interactions with pyridine molecules. A similar scenario was observed in the Raman spectra (Fig. 4b), where the intensities of the PO4 3⁻ (990 cm⁻1) and O-Nb-O (810 cm⁻1) signals decreased and the peaks became broader with lower HCl concentrations [39,40]. Additionally, the Nb-O oxide bond signal was detected in Raman spectra at 600 cm-1. The signal was absent in 12M NbOPO4 but became more visible in the 1M sample, indicating the formation of niobium oxide structures at lower acidities. The combined FT-IR and Raman results suggest a shift from Lewis acid sites (Nb=O oxide) to Brønsted acid sites (PO4 3⁻) as the HCl concentration increases, with a transition from 1M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 to 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2. 3.1.4 NH3-TPD results The acidity of reference NbOPO4 materials and Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts, prepared under varying HCl concentrations, was studied using NH3-TPD, and the results are presented in Fig. 5 a and 5b, respectively. The desorption of NH3 was observed in two temperature regions: T1 (100–320°C) corresponding to weak to medium acid sites, and T2 (320–500°C) representing strong acid sites [41,42]. Both NbOPO4 and Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 exhibited broad peaks in the 100–450°C range, indicating a range of weak to strong acid sites, though the distribution of these sites varied depending on the preparation conditions. In Fig. 5a, NbOPO4 materials prepared with 1–6M HCl displayed a prominent peak around 200°C, corresponding to weak to medium acid sites. As the HCl concentration increased (9–12M), the peak shifted to the 350–400°C range, indicating the presence of stronger acid sites. This shift is likely due to differences in the composition of acid sites. Based on the FT-IR and Raman data, the weak to medium acid sites in the lower HCl concentration samples could be attributed to Lewis acid sites from Nb(V)=O or weak Brønsted acid sites from Nb-OH groups [43,44]. These species formed due to the aggressive hydrolysis of the niobium precursor at lower HCl concentrations, resulting in NbOx aggregates rather than NbOPO4. In contrast, the increased strong acid sites at higher HCl concentrations are likely due to the formation of NbOPO4, which gives rise to surface –OPO3OH groups as strong Brønsted acid sites [37,45]. The higher the HCl concentration, the slower the crystallization rate, which allowed for greater exposure to phosphate species, leading to the formation of the NbOPO4 structure. In Fig. 5b and Table 1, Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts showed a similar trend, with a higher proportion of strong acid sites observed as the HCl concentration increased. Strong to weak acidity ratio of the Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 materials increased from 0.62 to 0.89 when increasing acidity from 1M to 12M during the catalyst preparation. However, since TiO2 was the dominant component in the catalysts, part of the peaks was covered by the acidity derived from the TiO2 support (middle peak as presented in SI 3). This suggests that the acidity from the TiO2 support also plays a role in enhancing the overall catalytic activity, contributing to the efficiency of the HDO process. 3.1.5 SEM-EDS and TEM The surface morphology and elemental distribution of the catalysts were studied using SEM-EDS and TEM, as illustrated both in Figs. 6 and 7 . Fig. 6 demonstrates that the resulting microcrystals in TiO2 structure remained unaffected by the synthesis conditions used for depositing NbOPO4 and Ru, unlike previous studies where concentrated H3PO4 caused significant degradation (up to 90%) of oxide supports' surface area and pore volume [46]. This observation is consistent with N2 physisorption analysis, which also showed minimal changes to the surface area and pore structure of the TiO2 support during the preparation of Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts (Table 1). The 1M, 3M, and 6M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 6b–d) exhibited Nb-based particles dispersed as sheet aggregates on the surface, likely amorphous in nature. EDS analysis further clarified the formation of these aggregates, showing Nb/P ratios of 1.76, 1.82, and 1.53, respectively (Table 1). This indicates that the catalysts contain more niobium than phosphate, suggesting that the aggregates could be partly composed of Nb2O5 species in addition to NbOPO4. In more acidic conditions, the 9M and 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts (Figs. 6e, f, SI 4) exhibited flower-like crystalline structures in some regions. The crystallinity of the catalysts is supported by a well-defined diffraction pattern characteristic of niobium oxyphosphate materials from the XRD results (Fig. 2). EDS mapping showed Nb/P ratios of 1.03 and 1.00, respectively, indicating an equal stoichiometry of niobium and phosphate, confirming that increased acidity promotes greater phosphorus integration into the catalyst. These results align with previous characterizations, highlighting acidity's influence on catalyst composition. Figs. 7a and SI 5 present the elemental maps of the Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst prepared at 9M condition, showing a uniform distribution of O, Ti, Nb, P, Ru, respectively, and none of the elements agglomerated under the used synthesis conditions. This indicates that the synthesis method effectively ensured uniform dispersion of phosphate groups and efficient doping of Ru particles on the surface. TEM analysis in Figs. 7b and SI 6 reveal a well-organized sheet structure with homogeneously dispersed Ru nanoparticles (∼2 nm in size) on all the surfaces of 1-12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts achieved via the incipient wetness method. This even decoration of Ru is crucial for improving catalytic performance, and smaller particles increase the surface area to volume ratio, providing more active sites for the HDO reaction. 3.2 Catalytic activity in HDO of lignin-model eugenol 3.2.1 Influence of reaction temperature The catalytic activity for hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) was initially evaluated at different temperatures. Each reaction was conducted for 12 h using Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts prepared under varying HCl concentrations (12M, 9M, and 6M), at 50 bar initial hydrogen pressure with cyclohexane as the solvent. The influence of reaction temperature (200 and 225°C) is shown in Table 2 and SI 7. At 225°C, all catalysts achieved complete conversion, with gas chromatography (GC) analysis revealing a high yield of 94–96% for the target product and no detectable oxygenates, demonstrating the catalysts' high effectiveness. To further investigate catalyst performance, additional tests were conducted at lower temperatures. At 200°C, catalytic activity remained almost unchanged for 12M catalyst while showing a slight decrease in conversion with 9M and 6M catalysts. The 9M catalyst was chosen to further at 175°C (Table 2, line 5), where it exhibited only moderate performance with about 58% hydrocarbon products obtained. The remaining substances were unreacted reagents and oxygenates. These results indicate that the catalyst gradually loses activity as the temperature decreased, probably due to a reduced number of effective collisions at lower temperatures. At 200°C and higher, the catalyst displayed prominent performance, which is slightly improved and consistent with findings from previous studies [47,48]. Based on these results, 200°C was chosen for further experiments. 3.2.2 Influence of reaction time The influence of the reaction time on the HDO of eugenol was investigated to maximize hydrocarbon selectivity. Reactions were conducted at 200°C and 50 bar H2 for 2, 4, 8, and 12 h using catalysts with varying HCl molarities: 12M, 9M, 6M, and 1M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2. The 3M catalyst was not extensively studied over different time intervals, as there were no significant differences in the characterization of this material compared to the 6M and 1M catalysts. The results, presented in Table 2 and Fig. 8 , show conversion and selectivity trends over the reaction time periods. Overall, conversion increased with longer reaction times for all catalysts (Fig. 8a). Minor changes in yield were observed between the 2- and 4-hour intervals. However, after 8 h, conversion significantly improved, exceeding 60% for all catalysts. By 12 h, conversion exceeded 80% for all catalysts except the 1M catalyst. Notably, the 12M catalyst achieved 100% conversion after 12 h (Fig. 8b). Selectivity toward the target hydrocarbon product also improved with time, increasing from 12% at 2 h to 95% at 12 h, accompanied by a decline in oxygenates. The results suggest that the reaction progresses through stages of double-bond saturation, deoxygenation, and catalytic C–O bond cleavage. In summary, this time-dependent study shows a critical conversion threshold at 8 h, with further gains achieved by extending the reaction to 12 h, highlighting the importance of sufficient reaction times for maximizing conversion and selectivity. 3.2.3 Influence of catalyst The catalytic activity of Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 materials synthesized under varying acidic conditions was evaluated for the HDO of eugenol to hydrocarbons. The reactions were performed at 200°C under 50 bar hydrogen pressure, using cyclohexane as the solvent. Results were compared with home-made Ru/TiO2 and commercial Ru/C catalysts, with data summarized in Table 2, SI 8, and Fig. 9 , which clearly depicts the superiority of multifunctional Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts in promoting selective HDO reaction. Overall, all Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts exhibited good activity, achieving over 50% selectivity toward the target product within 8–12 h of reaction time (Table 2). The catalytic differences among the 12M, 9M, 6M, 3M, and 1M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts are illustrated in SI 8. After 12 h, the 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst, characterized by a high composition of strong Brønsted acid sites, demonstrated superior performance, achieving complete conversion and a nearly 100% yield of hydrocarbons. The 9M and 6M catalysts also showed high activity, with eugenol conversions exceeding 80% and selectivity for the target product surpassing 70%. Meanwhile, the 1M catalyst, with predominantly weak Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, exhibited the lowest activity, with only 66% conversion. A similar trend was observed at the 8-hour mark, where conversion and hydrocarbon selectivity decreased as the HCl concentration used in catalyst preparation diminished. These findings emphasize the important role of acid site composition and strength in driving the HDO conversion and selectivity of the lignin-model compound, which is in agreement with previously reported publications [49,50], where metal phosphate catalysts such as Ni/AlPO4 and Ru/biochar catalyst coupled with silicotungstic acid facilitated the HDO of guaiacol with near-complete conversion and high selectivity of hydrocarbons. Overall in this study, the catalytic HDO performance of Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts followed the order: 12M > 9M > 6M > 3M > 1M. To further assess performance, Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts were compared to Ru/TiO2 (home-made) and Ru/C (commercial) in 12-hour reactions at 200°C. Results, detailed in Fig. 9 and Table 2, revealed distinct differences. Both Ru/TiO2 and Ru/C showed lower yields of hydrocarbons and the target product, with significant amounts of oxygenates remaining in the output. Ru/TiO2 achieved 54% selectivity for the target product, while Ru/C exhibited only 30%, in contrast to the 95% selectivity obtained with the 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst. The inferior performance of Ru/TiO2 and Ru/C was attributed to their lack of strong Brønsted acid sites, which are essential for effective C–O bond cleavage. However, the higher activity of Ru/TiO2 compared to Ru/C suggests that Lewis acid sites from TiO2 provide partial support for the HDO reaction, as described also in Ru/TiO2-catalyzed HDO of guaiacol in the research of Riyang Shu and coworkers [51]. Additionally, the moderate selectivity of 30% observed with Ru/C suggests a minor contribution of Ru (or RuOx) species to C–O bond cleavage, alongside their primary role in H2 activation. The Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts demonstrated superior catalytic performance compared to Ru/TiO2 and Ru/C, highlighting the important role of multifunctionality. The synergy between strong Brønsted acid sites, Lewis acid sites, and Ru particles in Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts was essential for achieving high conversion and selectivity toward hydrocarbons. These results highlight the importance of acid site composition and the interplay between catalyst components in enabling efficient HDO reactions. 3.2.4 Catalytic performance and catalyst reusability The catalytic performance of the 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst was further evaluated using other phenolic substrates under optimized conditions. HDO of 2-phenylphenol at 200 °C for 12 h resulted in 99% conversion, with a high selectivity of 89% towards hydrocarbon products, primarily bicyclohexyl and other bicyclic compounds. Similarly, HDO of diphenyl ether under similar reaction conditions yielded near-complete conversion, achieving 85% selectivity for hydrocarbon products, including cyclohexane and other monocyclics. These results suggest that the 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst exhibits broad applicability for the HDO of various phenolic compounds. To assess the operational stability of the Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts, reusability experiments were performed for the HDO of eugenol using 12M Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 under optimized reaction conditions (200 °C, 12 h). For each reusability test, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, thoroughly washed with acetone, dried at 100 °C, and reused in subsequent runs. The results, shown in Fig. 10 , indicate that conversion dropped slightly from 100% in the first run to 95–91% in later cycles, suggesting a 5–9% loss in catalytic activity over the course of the tests. This minor decrease in activity may be due to slight coking of organic molecules adsorbed over the surface, covering the active sites or blocking partly the pores; thereby restricting the reactant molecules to reach the active sites. To remove the organic cokes, the spent catalyst was recalcined at 450°C for 5 h under a 100 L h-1 flow of air. The regenerated catalyst gave a slightly increased conversion of eugenol (95%) under the same condition (Table 2). Since the loss of catalytic performance is less than 10% in each cycle and the elemental composition of the spent catalyst remained almost unchanged compared to the fresh material (SI 5), the Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst demonstrated good stability under the evaluated test conditions. 3.2.5 Kinetic studies To understand more about the reaction kinetics and mechanism, a preliminary kinetic study was conducted for all the catalysts at 200°C, over different time intervals. The system treated both reactants as processed in a batch reactor. Assuming the behavior of an ideal batch reactor, the material balance is used: d c ‾ d τ = r ‾ ( υ ‾ ‾ , R ‾ ) where ( r ‾ ) is the rate of consumption, ( υ ‾ ‾ ) is the reaction mechanism, and ( R ‾ ) is the reaction rate. To predict the behavior through the integration of material balances, an integral approach is employed for the kinetic studies. The integral approach focuses on the accumulation of concentrations over a specific period providing an overall view of the entire reaction process, highlighting the total change in concentrations from the start to the end of the reaction. The material balance is then described as follows: d c i d t = r i To solve analytically this equation, the experimental concentrations of the reactant are plotted over time. Then, the shape of the curves allows to make assumptions about the mechanism (ν) and the reaction rate (R). The reaction rate is a function of the concentrations (ci ) and additional parameters and is given as follows: R = k c i α where k is the kinetic constant of the reaction. Considering the initial balance of the species i, the theoretical material balance c i t h ( t ) can be solved using the following system of equations: { d c i d t = r i = υ i R = − k c i α c i ( 0 ) = c i 0 The experimental value c i e x p ( t ) is compared to the theoretical prediction c i t h ( t ) using the assumed mechanism and rate. The optimal parameters are those that approximate the best average of all experimental data. To evaluate the accuracy of the used parameters, the absolute value of the difference between the experimental and theoretical concentrations was evaluated simultaneously, as follows: D = | c i e x p ( t ) − c i t h ( t ) | The vector D comprises all the distances between experimental and theoretical concentrations. D varies with the parameters in the model, and a lower D indicates a superior model. Therefore, parameter values should be selected to minimize the distance between the model and the data. To combine these elements, a norm is applied. Following normalization, an objective function is formulated as follows: F O B J = ∥ D i , e x p − c a l c ∥ = ∑ i = 1 N D i 2 The objective function is then minimized using the Excel integrated function "Solver" by adjusting different parameters. This process identifies the value that best fits with the experimental data. To assess the accuracy of the objective function, a coefficient of determination (R2 ) was introduced, which determined the proportion of variance in the dependent variable c i t h ( t ) that can be explained by the independent variable c i e x p ( t ) . In this study, a preliminary kinetic analysis was conducted incorporating certain assumptions. Generally, to achieve a comprehensive understanding of the actual reaction rate and mechanism, it is essential to sample and analyze reaction products at various time points. However, due to prolonged reaction times and the experimental setup, stopping the reaction at different intervals was impractical. Instead, identical reactions under the same conditions were conducted at various time intervals. Besides, to determine the rate constant (k) and reaction rate, the concentration of the reactant in the final product was calculated from GC area peaks. Notably, variations in the initial concentration of the reactant occurred due to experimental errors. To address this, the initial concentration was averaged across different concentrations calculated for reactions conducted at various time intervals. Following the previously explained procedure and incorporating the assumptions, the preliminary kinetic study of the HDO of eugenol was conducted. The proposed reaction rate is as follows: R = k c E U G α 1 c H 2 α 2 The kinetic constant, denoted as k, was associated with the concentrations of eugenol (cEUG ) and molecular hydrogen (cH2 ), represented by α1 and α2 as the exponents of the concentrations of the two reactants. As all experiments were conducted with an excess of H2; for the sake of simplifying the kinetic study, it was assumed that the concentration of H2 remains constant and was incorporated into the kinetic constant. Consequently, the reaction rate was expressed as follows: R = k c E U G α According to the previous assumptions, the corresponding material balance for the eugenol HDO is shown as follows: d c E U G d t = r E U G = ν E U G R = − R To determine the order of the reaction of interest, concentration of the reactant was plotted over time for different catalytic conditions (1M, 6M, 9M and 12M) (Fig. 11 ). First-order dynamic of the reaction was assumed. Thus, α=1 was obtained. In this case, the material balance becomes: { d c E U G d t = r E U G = υ E U G R = − k c E U G c E U G ( 0 ) = c E U G 0 And the corresponding analytical solution is as follows: c E U G t h = c E U G 0 exp ( − k t ) The hypothesis was implemented in Excel, and an initial guess of the parameters was given. This allowed the estimation of the kinetic rate constant k and the R2 of the regression for each curve. The initial guess and the final results for k are reported in SI 9, showing the comparison between the experimental curve c E U G e x p ( t ) and the theoretical curve c E U G t h ( t ) with respect to the reaction time. It was observed that the calculated curve, although not perfectly fitting experimental data, provides a viewpoint of an HDO process that is highly dependent on the concentration of the lignin-model compound eugenol. The reaction rate decreases steadily as the eugenol concentration is consumed, with the highest eugenol concentration (∼300 mM) being effectively accommodated by the available active sites of the catalysts. When projecting these findings to HDO reactions of lignin, it suggests that initial cleavage might be challenging due to lignin's bulky structure on the catalyst surface. However, as the reaction progresses and smaller fragments form, the catalysts become increasingly efficient. While this kinetic study provides a valuable starting point, further investigation into reaction dynamics including catalyst behavior, adsorption-desorption mechanisms, and external factors, is necessary and can produce more comprehensive models for the HDO of lignin-model compounds. 3.2.6 Proposed reaction mechanism Based on the results, a preliminary reaction mechanism was proposed, as depicted in Scheme 1 . This mechanism outlines the conversion of the lignin-model compound eugenol 1 through a four-step catalytic cycle, with the catalyst being regenerated at the end of each cycle. 1. Hydrogenation: The process begins with the saturation of the double bonds in eugenol’s external carbon chain, followed by the benzene ring. These saturations are facilitated by atomic hydrogen produced through the activation of H2 on the Ru component. 2. Ether bond activation: In the next step, the ether bond in 2 is activated by the Lewis acid sites of the catalyst. 3. Ether bond cleavage: The strong Brønsted acid sites then assist in cleaving the activated ether bond, leading to significant structural transformations in intermediate 3. 4. Hydroxyl bond cleavage and product formation: In the final stages of the reaction, primarily after 8 to 12 h, the -OH bond is also activated and cleaved, resulting in the formation of a carbocation that leads to the target product 4 along with small amounts of other hydrocarbons 5 via structural rearrangement, which are still considered valuable products. Each component of the multifunctional catalyst plays a crucial role in achieving high conversion and selectivity under the applied reaction conditions. The Ru component drives hydrogenation, while the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites catalyze activation, bond cleavage, and intermediate transformations. The reaction proceeds via hydrogenation, catalytic activation, cracking, and isomerization pathways, demonstrating the synergy among these catalytic functions [15,52]. The reaction conditions employed in this study represent a notable improvement compared to traditional HDO reactions. The catalysts operated effectively at a relatively low temperature of 200°C, a considerable reduction from the temperatures traditionally utilized in HDO reactions, usually much greater than 225°C. Additionally, the reaction was performed under mild pressure and time-efficient conditions, although further optimization of parameters may enhance performance. The mechanism and its associated conditions highlight the effectiveness and potential of these multifunctional Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts for lignin-model compound conversion. 4 Conclusions This study presents an efficient, liquid phase H3PO4-free hydrothermal method for synthesizing highly dispersed, high-surface-area, multifunctional and active mesoporous Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts. The catalytic activity of Ru and the acidic NbOPO4 sites was significantly enhanced due to the improved dispersion of active species over the mesoporous TiO2 structure. Structural analysis of the catalysts synthesized under varying acidity conditions revealed a transition from an amorphous NbOPO4 structure at lower HCl molarities (1M, 3M, 6M) to a more crystalline structure at higher concentrations (9M and 12M). Additionally, the Brønsted-to-Lewis acid site ratio increased with acidity, indicating tunable acidic properties ranging from weak to medium and strong acid sites. Notably, the structural integrity of TiO2 was preserved in the supported catalysts. The catalytic performance was demonstrated in the HDO of the lignin-model compound eugenol into hydrocarbons. The 12M 2.5 wt.% Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalyst, prepared under concentrated HCl conditions and enriched with strong Brønsted acid sites, exhibited good activity and selectivity, outperforming 2.5 wt.% Ru/TiO2, 5 wt.% Ru/C, and other Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts under the very same reaction condition of 200°C and 50 bar H2. The mesoporous TiO2 support also contributed to the catalyst's stability, enabling excellent reusability. Overall, the Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts developed in this study show superior catalytic activity and surface properties, making them suitable not only for lignin valorization but also for other industrial applications of converting bio-based macromolecules into valuable products. coredata.dc:description: Lignin valorization has attracted significant attention in recent years due to its abundance and potential as a renewable organic carbon resource to produce a variety of value-added chemicals and fuel additives. Catalytic upgrading of lignin faces challenges due to its complex structure and an active catalyst with selective surface properties is needed to break the stable C–O and C–C interunit linkages. In the present work, we developed a series of multifunctional Ru/NbOPO4/TiO2 catalysts with varying surface acidic properties and explored their potential upon hydrogenolysis of lignin model compound eugenol. Textural and surface acidic properties of the prepared materials were studied by means of different techniques such as N2-physisorption, NH3-TPD, XRD, SEM-EDS, Raman spectra, FT-IR, and TEM. Our catalytic results revealed synergistic role of acid and metal sites upon catalyst performance, whereupon high yields of hydrocarbons (86.9–100 wt.%) were obtained with selective cleavage of the methoxy and hydroxy groups under milder conditions. A kinetic study further identified the reaction mechanism and determined a rate law and partial reaction orders. This research advances the understanding of catalyst design for upgrading of the lignin or lignin monomers into value added chemicals. and on the other hand, contributes to sustainable development by maximizing biomass usage and providing environmentally friendly alternatives in renewable energy.
